subtasks.hazard: Negligent discharge or weapon malfunction causing harm

values: Daily safety briefs for soldiers
Soldiers treat weapons as if they were loaded at all times
Proper Mechanical and electrical safety operations
Weapon clearance from RSO before exit of range
VCs clear all weapons at conclusion of live firing
RSO will personally inspect all cleared weapons prior to movement off of range.
Vehicles with weapons malfunctions will remain in BP or move to clearing pit until cleared.
Malfunctions which cannot be cleared by crew will be cleared by the Squadron Master Gunner or Field Service Reps.
-Gunney Skills Test certification -Conduct Safety Brief -Leadership inspect clearance/ weapon safeties
VCs, MG, RSO/OIC, SLs

MG/RSO observe for rounds impacting outside range fan; cease fire as required.

Vehicles will follow posted speed limits and proper following distances while driving/convoying within GTA
Troop Commanders are the release authority for movement between ranges, based on assessment of Crew rest.
All Troopers wear PPE, seatbelts, and gunners restraints when moving inside tactical vehicles.
Convoy CDRs inspect licenses as well as conduct standard convoy brief prior to any movement of, vehicles within GTA

All Troopers wear PPE, seatbelts, and gunners restraints when moving inside tactical vehicles.

-Convoy Commanders execute standard convoy brief and safety inspection prior to SP. -Standard PMCS and dispatching procedures -Monitor posted road conditions.
Convoy Commanders, PLs, PSGs, SLs
Snow chains will be on board each vehicle

-Main Command Post updates road GTA road conditions through O&I nets. -Commanders at echelon exercise approval authority based on GTA road condition SOP. -Brief inclement weather conditions during safety brief -Inspect snow chains during PCC/PCIs

subtasks.hazard: Unauthorized personnel entering the range or authorized personnel entering the range with the wrong equipment

values: Gate guards will be placed at the required access points in order to monitor all traffic on and off the range.
Range flag will be posted during live firing IAW GTA Range SOP.
Ensure anyone entering the range has proper PPE according to the 1/2 CR Dragoon Standard
Personnel at range gates conduct standard gate guard brief to incoming personnel onto the range
-Gate Guards provided standard script and communication to RSO / OIC
RSO, Gate guard, backside support NCIOC
Soldiers will not sleep near, on, or underneath a vehicle due to risk of death and carbon monoxide poisoning
Sleeping areas will be located inside hard structures on range complex
Leaders will ensure soldiers understand where barracks are located and soldiers are not sleeping near vehicles prior to bedding down
RSO, OIC, SLs, TLs

Ammo NCOIC will ensure that only authorized ammunition is distributed from the authorized Ammo Point
Unit Leaders, Safeties, and Crews will be briefed on all authorized ammunition. They will ensure that only authorized ammunition is utilized in the correct manner during the execution of Gunnery

No smoking within 50 feet of ammo point

Ammo Point inspected by MG, RSO, and Distro Team. S3 TREX team conducts spot checks of all ammunition storage locations.
Ammo NCOIC, OIC, RSO, MG, Distro Platoon, S3 TREX
Brief Crews on procedures during limited visibility conditions
Soldiers will use Thermal optics, DVEs, and RWS TIM/FLIR during limited visibility and night time operations
Ground guides will be used during times of degraded visibility
Use white lights when needed off of range
Use of chem lights for proper marking of areas and personnel
-Separate safety brief conducted prior to night fire

If a fire occurs, OIC will immediately notify Range Control and put the range in "COLD" status
NCOIC will have a fire fighting detail ready to put out any fires
-Firefighting rehearsal executed during backside support rehearsal -Instruction included in Safety Brief
MG, OIC, RSO, NCIOC

draw.overall_supervision_plan: Vehicular accidents during movement to, from, and between training locations remains the most likely and dangerous hazard for this training event. This will be mitigated in three steps: 1) The Squadron main command post ensures that leaders understand current road conditions in the training area. 2) Commanders exercise their movement approval authority based on their assessment of road conditions, crew rest, and other risk factors. 3) Once a movement is approved, convoy commanders execute standard convoy briefs and safety inspections, and control their convoys once underway. Once crews arrive to gunnery training, the range OIC and RSO become primarily responsible implementing and monitoring risk controls. Risk mitigations (to include CASEVAC procedures) will be rehearsed during the backside support rehearsal and exercised during the TEWT. The Master Gunner, OIC, RSO, NCOIC, and Medics will conduct a range safety brief to all  personnel executing and supporting training. Leaders at echelon observe their crews and stop any unsafe act.With these mitigations in place, the overall residual risk for this event is low.
